review.title: Universal probability-free prediction
review.abstract: We construct a universal prediction system in the spirit of Popper's falsifiability and Kolmogorov complexity. This prediction system does not depend on any statistical assumptions, but under the IID assumption it dominates, although in a rather weak sense, conformal prediction.

It is not for nothing that we call the laws of nature "laws": the more they prohibit, the more they say.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this paper, we look at the problem of predicting labels that are assumed to be binary, a sequence of objects. This is an online version of the standard problem of binary classification, because we will be interested in endless sequences of observations, where X is an object space and 2: = {0, 1}. For the sake of simplicity, we assume that X is a given finite set of, say, binary strings (where the intuition is that finite objects can always be encoded as binary strings). Finite sequences of observations are referred to as negative data sequences.

sections.heading: 2 Laws of nature as prediction systems
sections.text: According to Popper's [1] view of the philosophy of science, natural laws should be falsifiable: if a finite sequence of observations contradicts such a law, we should be able to recognize it. (Popper often preferred to talk about scientific theories or statements rather than natural laws.) The empirical content of a natural law is the amount of its potential falsifiers ([1], Sections 31 and 35). We begin by formalizing this term in our toy setting and interpret the requirement that we should be able to detect falsifications in such a way that we should be able to detect them. sections.heading: 3 Strong prediction systems
sections.text: The idea of a natural law is static; experience tells us that natural laws ultimately fail and are replaced by other laws. Popper presented his picture of this process through formulas ("evolutionary schemes") that PS1 → TT1 → EE1 → PS2 → · · (2) (introduced in his 1965 lecture, on which [2], Chapter 6, is based and discussed in several other places in [2] and [3]; in our notation we follow Wikipedia). In response to a problem situation PS, a preliminary theory TT is subjected to attempts at error removal, the success of which leads to a new problem situation, and scientists come up with a new preliminary theory TT, etc. In our toy version of this process, preliminary theories are laws of nature, problem situations situations where our current law of nature is falsified, and there are no active attempts at error removal.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Analogous to the Kolmogorov Complexity Theory, we expect the simplest and most elegant results to be achieved for computational models that are more flexible than Turing machines, such as Kolmogorov-Uspensky algorithms and beauty machines.
